2025-07-10T16:38:58.959954Z assistant

Excellent fresh start!

However, just so we're clear:

I dont have the ability to directly click through your GitHub repo in real time on my own. I can't browse the web in that way.

But you can absolutely do this instead:

Copy and paste the link to the specific notebook file (e.g. its raw GitHub URL).
Or download the notebook .ipynb file and upload it here.
Or copy-paste the cell contents here.

Once you do that, I can:

  • Read the entire notebook (or the parts you share)
  • Help review edits, spot errors, propose refinements
  • Help with formatting, structuring, and rewriting sections

Basically, I can work with anything you give me from that repo I just cant fetch it automatically.

TL;DR

I can't navigate your repo live. But if you share the notebook contents here, we can edit together line by line, cell by cell, section by section.

When you're ready, send over the first bit you'd like to work on!

2025-07-10T16:41:22.387000Z user

if only i fucking knew how to god damned copy from a notebook cell successfully and paste it into here

2025-07-10T16:41:23.099758Z assistant

Hah! I feel you. Lets get you unstuck.

Heres a super simple, step-by-step to copy text out of a Jupyter Notebook cell.

If youre in JupyterLab or classic Jupyter Notebook in the browser:

1 Click once on the cell you want to copy.
2 Double-click inside the cell to enter edit mode (so you see the raw text, not just rendered Markdown).
3 Select the text with your mouse or keyboard.
4 Right-click Copy (or use Ctrl+C / Cmd+C).
5 Come here and Paste (Ctrl+V / Cmd+V).

If youre in VS Codes notebook interface:

1 Click the cell to select it.
2 Click Edit Cell (pencil icon) if its Markdown.
3 Select all text inside.
4 Copy / paste as normal.

If it's a really stubborn notebook (e.g. read-only render on GitHub):

  • Click Raw view on GitHub.
  • Copy the plain text.

If you tell me:

Im using JupyterLab / classic Notebook / VS Code / GitHub only

2025-07-10T16:42:55.236070Z assistant

Excellent youre describing a classic Linux browser annoyance.

TL;DR: The Jupyter notebook cell in the browser just needs regular Ctrl+C when youre inside edit mode.

Heres the quickest way to fix your problem:

You're likely copying the cell itself (which is metadata) instead of its text contents.

Try these steps carefully:

1 Click the cell once.
2 Double-click inside the cell so you see the text cursor blinking in the text. (It must switch to raw text-edit mode!)
3 Select the actual text inside with your mouse.
4 Now hit Ctrl+C (not Ctrl+Shift+C thats a terminal thing!)

On Ubuntu in the browser:

  • Ctrl+Shift+C opens dev tools. Ignore that.
  • You want Ctrl+C only, while the text is highlighted.

Alternate (foolproof) way if that still fails

If your Jupyter is stubborn:
1 Click inside the cell to edit it.
2 Manually select all the text and right-click Copy.

Absolute fallback

If none of that works:

  • Go to the .ipynb file on disk.
  • Open it with any text editor (VS Code, Sublime, Gedit).
  • Search for your cells content in the JSON.
  • Copy it directly from there.

Alternative Ultimate Easy Method:

Export notebook to .py script: 1 In Jupyter: File Download as Python (.py) 2 Open the .py file in any text editor. 3 Copy the cell contents from there.

Shortest answer:

Inside the notebook cell, double-click to edit it. Select text. Hit Ctrl+C. Paste here.

If you tell me:

Im in JupyterLab / Classic Notebook / VS Code / JupyterLite / Colab

Ill give you super-specific steps for that exact environment.

When you're ready, just paste the text here, and Ill start fixing it.

Well get this done one tiny obstacle at a time, no stress.

2025-07-10T16:43:22.074000Z user

Prologue Complete Edits

"The End was Set We all were There Before, when all that is was yet And so We watched As nothing stopped The Beginning, where We all met"

It was quite peculiar that *this* woman - of all people - just so happened to be in *this* place, at *this* time, if only for the very simple --yet quite inexplicable-- fact she hand't yet been born, and wouldn't for another five months. Perhaps even more unexplainable was the fact that not only was she fully grown, but also she possessed the knowledge gained from countless thousands of past incarnations. But none of that was relevant at the moment. There *were* more pressing issues at hand. There was no time to waste arguing the semantics of escaping time loops, and after all -- she was not your average woman anyway.
The mystery of her presence was quite unimportant in retrospect. How she had gotten there, inconsequential. All that mattered was she Had arrived, and so had they. He would be arriving soon, and things had  best be in place be for he did. Everything *must* be in order before he appeared -- For indeed the world *had* been awaiting his return for a very long time.
Things were taking place that would soon affect the very framework of reality, touching every portion of existence. Nothing would be the same. Thus was the topic of conversation this night between three key individuals.


"You do realize of course just what this plan of yours means?" she asked sternly, gazing out of the window as lightning crashed all around. The Storm inched ever closer to them.
"I know of *no other* option... The Connection *must* be made." replied the man with green eyes, his voice detached and somewhat fearful tone.
"I'm afraid this has become something far more demanding than any of us ever dreamed." the other man said. He sat calmly in a recliner nearby, smoking a long pipe, his face wrinkled with concern. They both loved him so deeply. The three of them had been together for so long--fighting the same foe--and while she might not have been prone to showing her weakness before mere mortals, he knew he wasn't alone. They both found it hard to believe just what the man with green eyes was considering. So much pain, yet none of it seemed necessary. Then again, no one had asked their opinion.
After a long pause, the woman said in a contemplative tone, "There simply *must* be another way! He shouldn't have to..." she stopped suddenly, realizing what she'd nearly said. The words had slipped out, unbidden.
"*That* is precisely why he *must*!" came a fourth voice, one *very* familiar to all three.
Their eyes turned in unison towards the darkened corner the intruder occupied. This was supposed to have been a private meeting. How had he found them? The woman, whose presence before had been a calming and peaceful emanation--Her attempt at helping her two friends cope--suddenly, turned a darker shade. Within an instant her anger kindled to such a degree her companions began trembling with an uneathly and holy fear. Her ferocity seemed to shake the very fabric of reality, fracturing the air around them. None of this seemed to frighten the intruder in the least. He just stared back at her, a serene look upon his face and he strolled closer into view.
"How *dare* you!" she roared, the lighthouse shuddering in her wake, "How dare you bring your nonsense *here* of all places! This is more than a man's *life* we're talking about, not some whimsical concept in your befuddled mind! A man, who just so happens to be a very *dear* friend of mine. Yet *still* you've come uninvited and with you brought the audacity to spout off your insane ramblings and--as always-- speaking with that same venmous tone as you always do, as if *we* are the uninformed!"
He said nothing in retort, but instead looked deeply into her eyes. The man had appeared silently. He hand't used a door. In fact, he didn't even climb the stairs to the top of the lighthouse where the three had gathered, and indeed, he had *not* been invited, but such things didn't matter, and yet was another reason he remained unafraid of this dreadfully perilous woman. They all three needed him, and they knew it--regardless of how illaccepted his presence was.
"...But... he's right..." said the man in the chair, a forlorn look upon his face as he paused in his smoking.
"Indeed I am." He glared menacingly at the woman as he strolled all the more into view, "I would *think* one of *The Preori* would *know better* than to confuse her *emotions* with the *facts*! Perhaps my dear, it's simply your humanity *finally* shining through?" he asked with a slight smile forming upon his face, eyes twinkling in the dim light. He winked surreptitiously to the man in the chair.
The woman turned upon him again, but before she could unleash her rage, she was interrupted.
"Listen you two..." the man with the green eyes paused thoughtfully, "it is *my* choice. You know he is already on his way--even now--We don't have *time* to sit around arguing. We know what *must* be done. There's only one way to ensure *The Connection* is made. Otherwise they'll delay it for as long as they can. You know how they work. *The Game* is rigged, and I know it goes against everything we stand for, but *if* we're going to win this war..." he paused again, as if seeking the courage to continue on, "and we *must*...We're going to *have* to get our hands dirty. There's simply no way around it."
The intruder interrupted once more--he was quite good at that, "And *I* can think of none better suited to tread so deeply into darkened territory than you, and see to it the job gets done." he said satisfactorily.
The man in the chair covered his face in pain. The intruder *was* right, and now, all three of them knew it. The woman suddenly looked as if the wind had went out of her sails. The strange man's words cut through her like a knife, and right to the bone as so often they did. She *was* being emotional, just as he said, and *indeed*--it *was* due to her inability to deal with her... *unique* nature that was causing her to remain so thoroughly rattled. She hated how he always did this to her. Why had *she* been cursed with the blessing of existing in two worlds simultaneously? It *was* difficult being the only of her kind in all of existence. She had none with whom she could relate, and sometimes, *this* was the hardest part.
The green-eyed man thanked the intruder with a nod then continued, "Listen I know none of this seems fair... to either one of you. Hell--none of it seems fair to me either. I'm not even sure I *can* do it. The fear alone is..." his voice faltered, "The thought itself is paralyzing... but... it *must* be done. This is after all just a game. A wicked one... but a game, neverhteless. I know what I mean to both of you. To say goodbye *indefinitely* is near unbearable for *me*, especially since it's all just a gamble anyway." he paused again, "Things are so fragile and ... Unforseeable, but there's no way around it. *Someone* *has* to at the very lease try! We know He will remain to weak, unaware and forgetful to be of any use at all until *The Connection* has been made. Our only purpose is to ensure he is protected until that time comes." he took a deep breath, "This *has* to end. All of it. All of these unsuspecting people... If we won't do it for the sake of getting the job done, then at least let us persist on their behalf. This *has* to end... It just..." The green-eyed man's voice broke again with emotion as he remembered the true horror of what they were up against, "It just... *has* to..."
The intruder sighed pleasantly. He work was done. As usual, he'd completed his task without putting forth much effort at all. In fact, most of the time his mere presence was all that was necessary. It *had* been a long and arduous road. For ages it seemed he had interferred with the Dark Ones. It often left him isolated, even from his somewhat *mistrusting* allies. They never seemed to listen. They never chose to understand. But what he'd just heard comforted him greatly. The green-eyed man finally understood what was required, and even more, was willing to follow through. The intruder could ask for nothing more. Things must play out as they would.
You see, this was no ordinary man who was even now on his way. This was the *trump card*. The incalculable anomaly, sent to undo all of the evil instituted by *The Game*. *He* was the one they spoke of. The man referenced so frequently in *The Book*. All that remained was to wait for him to arrive, now that the green-eyed man understood his own path.
The woman sighed in frustration, "I understand *why* such things are necessary. I...I just don't want to lose you. I've witnessed the two of you lose so much and it's heartbreaking enough... I'm not sure I can handle..." her voice trailed off until she spoke mainly to herself, "...Humanity is so... frail..." she whispered.

2025-07-10T16:48:58.316000Z user

Chapter One

Chapter 1 : Follow Me - Complete Edits

He walked into Brian's life with very little warning or discretion at all, and though it was not a complete surprise--for Brian had knowledge of his own--A sliver of fear crept its way into his heart. The man had used his *real name* for one, and Brian had never met the man before. It was peculiar indeed. Strangers didn't often know his *real* name. Brian was in for a wild ride, and despite all that would soon come crashing into his life, fate could not have picked a more pecuiliarly *mundane* setting. Our story begins in a coffee shop one morning, as Brian sat there, checking his email.
"Brian McCord, what are you doing with your life?" the stranger asked abruptly, mocking him it seemed. No introduction. No opening woords. Just a blatant and somewhat rude, attention grabbing jeer. To Brian the man seemed fully intent on catching him off guard. However, Brian wasn't prone to such things.
He turned around, half expecting this. He'd felt it coming for some time. Though he had not known just when or where such a thing would manifest. When Brian looked up, the man was glaring back at him, eyes green and menacing. As it was not in Brian's nature to wear this emtions on his sleeve, he calmly lowered his sunglassings, meeting the gaze. Brian's steely grey eyes pierced into the man with a matched intensity. He smirked, attempting to throw *the stranger* off of *his* game.
The Stranger frowned knowingly, shaking his head, "Oh don't give me that! You're absolutely terrified!" he exclaimed, a sinister smile creeping across his face, his voice ending in a hiss, "Do you know *who* I am?", eyes flaring which hinted at some dark and hidden hunger. The stranger moved like a snake, repositioning himself in front of Brian's table.
At this Brian casually took his sunglasses the rest of the way off, laying them down and taking a drink of his coffee as if bored, but when he looked again, the man was nearly breathing down his throat.
"It is time!" he hissed, green eyes flashing with lightning it seemed. 
Brian didn't so much as flinch, though... He probably should have. After all, he *hadn't* seen the man move, not even in his peripheral. One moment he'd been a safe distance away... and the next, he'd invaded Brians personal space, again - Intentionally.
Brian maintained his bored demeanor, "And you ser are?" he inquired nonchallantly.
An evil and knowing smile formed upon the stranger's lips, raising his eyebrows suggestively as he said, "Oh... Don't you worry about that... Just follow me!" and with that the strange man turned swiftly around, one arm behind his back as he strode confidently towards the door and upon exiting the cafe, flung the door open with a shove so forceful it nearly knocked over the elderly couple seeking to enter at that same time. He muttered something Brian couldn't make out however that appeared to offend the couple so much that nearly being hit with the door seem trivial at best. Odder still, he didn't so much as look back to make sure Brian followed, even after such a rude display of theatrics.
...But Brian did follow. He didn't know why. He didn't even ponder it much. His feet began moving before he realized it, and for some reason, he let them go. It was as if he were being pulled by a current, against which there *could be no fighting*. That is not to say he necessarily *wanted* to combat it. Brian had known of this day for many years, and though he dreaded to see its arrival--partially for reasons he didn't yet understand--something about the man intrigued him. Plus, he was due for a date with a cigarette, and smoking wasn't allowed inside.
This was the excuse he used to quell the arrogance in his mind,  which seemed to disagree with him showing any interest in the least. You see, the *strangeness* of this event was not what led him to gather his laptop, coffee, and half-eaten breakfast. It was not the man's strange movements or speed which caused him to place his belongings into his car, lock it, then look around for the direction he had taken. No, not even the odd glimmer in the man's eyes which seemed more compelling than his knowledge of Brian's name had set his feet to walking, lighting a cigarette once he'd spotted him. None of this interested Brian at all. However, it was the *inexplicable* strangness of the walk itself that caused him to increase his pace, and this was very out of character for the young man. 
    Brian had noticed, by chance as it were, just how fast the man was walking and yet--somehow--the distance between them stayed fixed. Brian you see began following at his usual slow and steady, almost half-bored pace, unconcerned--or so he thought--with whether or not the man escaped his field of vision, but when Brian made *this* odd observation, he decided it best to test the crazed idea that surfaced in his mind. With all that had just transpired in the last few moments, what could it hurt to just *go with the flow*?
    He began at first to walk slightly faster, gaging his speed with the steps of the strange man, who, as Brian also noted, had not bothered to look back, *not even once* to check on his progress. When it became apparent to him that the man had not sped up, nor that the distance between them had changed in the slightest--for Brian was exactly a full block behind him--He broke out into a slight job, carefully watching to ensure the man was indeed *still just walking*. Sure enough, the man's gait had not adjusted... but then again, neither had the distance between them.
    This was not the first time somthing of this nature had appeared in Brian's life. He was twenty-three now, and until this point he'd always experienced periods of time--which fizzled out eventually--wherein it seemed as if the whole of the universe--God as some may call it--were attempting to tell him... *something*... Several times he'd followed hopelessly after various "signs and wonders" only to be let down in the end, as his extra-sensory perception of the world slowly slipped away into oblivion, leaving him questioning everything all the more.
    He'd written it off as a dream the first time he'd been approached in a like manner. He was only nine at the time, though the man he'd encountered then had been quite the opposite of this *new stranger*. He had made a point of ignoring all of the other odd people who'd come afterwards, each saying strange things and beckoning him to follow them. Despite this he'd never managed to shake his questions as to just *who* that first man had been.
    At nineteen he sat for weeks, alone in his bedroom poring over a large stack of books and compiling hundreds of seemingly deranged and disjointed notes. When he emerged, he ventured into the wilderness nearby and found that very same man in a small cabin, deep in the obscure forest... At the very least he knew that man was indeed real and not just some figment within his imagination. This revelation had troubled him deeply. When the man asked how he'd come to find his cabin, Brian had said that he'd simply "Followed The Stars".
    By twenty-one he'd grown quite comfortable with the apparently hidden realm of knowledge he'd somehow stumbled upon which seemed so contradictory towards what most considered "Reality". Indeed, there had often been times throughout Brian's life when random things--seemingly unrelated events--would occur in accordance with his thoughts, as though everything around him knew him personally. For the most part, by now he'd learned it best simply to ignore such sensations. Nevermind the fact he could no longer explain away the existence of the man in the cabin--He'd realized rather painfully however, that far too often following after such strange thoughts always left him at a dead-end. A barren space--wherein things were neither resolved, nor truly broken.
    He'd also learned it was best to keep quiet about such things after one evenings chat with his sisters--one older, the other younger. They'd immediately pointed him in the direction of a psychiatric ward, citing various articles on the dangers of *schizophrenia*. He actually had taken their advice at one point. A time when his mind seemed to be unravelling by the seams, but when he'd told the doctor he feared he was going insane, the man had laughed at him, then reassuringly said, "No my boy, you see, crazy people don't *know* they're crazy." and suggested he simply try to get more sleep. 
    Braight tried to take everything in stide, and despite possessing a very powerful "sixth sense" or intuitive notion about *most* things, he now rarely let himself become too enmeshed with the narrative's inherent drama. He routinely ignored the underlying strangeness of the world around him, blending it all in rather nicely with the rest of the odd characters he encountered--people who seemed to know him in some fashion or another--which is why his reaction on *this* day was quite out of the ordinary indeed.
    He began running after the jogging experiment failed to bring him *any* closer to the man. He was now convinced there was *indeed* some sort of a gulf fixed between them, as if--dare he say--by magic, as it were. The pursuit seemed to go on for at least a good half-hour. He'd tried everything he could to close or even extend the gap, but it was all in vain. Once Brian even stopped entirely but it too was to no avail. The man just kept on goin, yet never seemed to get any further away. Brian curiously found himself suddenly actually *wanting* to talk to the stranger after all. *This* was most *definitely* out of character for the young man.
    After leading Brian to a rather poor looking side of town, the man turned swiftly down an alleyway, in between two apartment buildings. As Brian rounded the corner, he saw the man open a door, then slam it closed behind him. His eyes widended. He made his way past the dangling clothesline and bits of scattered trash that littered the alleyway, and then came acrtoss yet *another* bewitching and auspicious symbol. He stared, transfixed by the numbers which glared back at him.
    Throughout Brian's odd life a tapestry of patterened and coded number schemes inexplicably seemed to not only appear, but also somehow hed a specific meaning he had no rational means of explaining. The timing of their appearances always emphasized this in dramatic and impossible ways. This phenomenon did nothing to change what he felt, nor dull the shocking intensity this particular configuration inflicted however. The number in question was one that had haunted him ever since his mother died. He was only sixteen at the time and she had just turned forty. You see the apartment was labeled six-hundred fourteen, and to Brian, any combination of the three numbers, one, six and four, had always said to him the same thing. *Death!* plain and simple.
    He thought for a breif moment of leaving. Returning to his car and going home, but luckily for us all, his ego urged him onward. Without any further hesitation or outward show of fear, he confidently turned the handle, only to find the door dead bolted. This baffled him profusely, and after giving the knob another futile turn, he decided instead to knock, unsure suddenly if the man he'd follow even existed. 
    On his third knock and almost instride with his hand, the door swung open and a different voice met him. 
    "Ah Mr. Johnson, it's so nice to *finally* meet you. Please, won't you come inside?"
    This was not the voice of the man he'd followed. no, this was not the same man at all.
    "We've been waiting for you," a familiar and snakelike voice concluded.
    As Brian peered inside he saw the man with the green eyes. He sat in a large velvet recliner, and was smiling wickedly back at him.
    "Please, come in." said the man at the door once more. He was short and chubby - wearing th eoddest of clothes. A full tuxedo.
    Brian was now unsettled to say the least. In fact, he'd secretly hoped it was indeed all just a hallucination. The man he had followed was not real at all, and the whole thing had been a farce--yet there he sate, just inside, smiling sinisterly. He again began to doubt his choice to ever abandon his breakfast. He stood there hesitantly, attempting to assess the safety of the situation from behind his dark sunglasses. He naturally felt as though he were being deceived in some fashion. 
    The man in the tux though was insistent and began gesturing with his hand, "Please Mr. Johnson, *do* come inside, we have *much* to discuss."
    "How do you know my name?" asked Brian sternly, once more on the defensive.
    The man had such an inviting face, round and comforting, upon it wearing a warm smile, but when Brain said this, the smile just... disappeared...
    "Yes! How *does* he known you're *name* Mr. McCord?" hissed the green-eyed man from his chair, "Come in please so Elvis can shut the door!"
    Brian laughed to himself, though his face did not show it. The man at the door indeed looked like a shorter, fattter, rendition of Elvis. However, the irony of the situation didn't lower Brian's guard in the slightest. If anything, it caused him to be all the more cautious. These men knew both his real name and alias--he'd put quite a bit of energy and money into keep the correlation from becoming public knowledge. They seemed to be mocking him about it. He wasn't yet fully persuaded, and he had a sense their intentions weren't as pure as they seemed to be trying so desparately to suggest--though they also seemed not to care much about hiding their subterfuge either.


Feeling suddenly as if he could reassert control, Brian decided to test their resolve.
"No... You tell me *now* how both of you seemingly know me... or I'm going home."
Much to his surprise, they responded rather oppositely than he expected. You see, Brian thought they needed *him* for something, and the idea had not yet crossed his mind that it infact was the other way around. 
The two men looked at each other, shrugged in unison, and said "Have it your way."
Elvis slammed the door shut. 
Brian heard the deadbolt slide back into place, and after a few breif seconds of confusion, knocked once more. *Again a most unnature choice of actions on his part* Normally, despite the strangeness, Brian actually would have just left, purposefully forgetting about the whole affair, but *something* seemed to refuse to allow him this privilege.
When the door opened again, Brian wasted no time before confidently striding inside. He said nothing, and when the door shut behind him the room grew dark, forcing him to remove his sunglasses. The only light infact was a small lamp sitting on an end table, situated in the far corner between the recliner and sofa. The room was neat. *too neat* it seemed, especially for this side of town. The books upon the shelves were all in aphabetical order and the white high pile carpet was pristine. The light from the lamp bounced off the walls, giving the room an eerie yellowish glow. The window had been boarded up, and over it hung a portrait of a dashingly beautiful woman dressed in a thin white gown, her long, silvery-blonde hair brushed neatly over the front of her shoulders. The parquet inlay near the door seemed polished as it gleamed in the dim light.
"Oh please, do have a seat Mr. McCord, there are some things we would like to go over with you." said the stranger with the green eyes, gesturing him towards the couch, "And don't worry, we'll tell you *everything* you want to know, but first," the man pointed once more, "You must sit."
"Would you like some tea Mr. Johnson?" the fat man asked.
Brian made his way across the room, "No *Elvis*, but thank you." he replied, a hint of sarcasm in his tone. He glanced up at the portrait over the window as he passed, feeling a shiver run first down, and then back up his spine as he did. It seemed as though her gaze had pierced through to his very soul as it were, and she seemed... vaguely familiar.
It was clear though the aparment was situated in the very worst part of town, no poor man lived here, and odder still, as Brian sat down and sank into his seat, he also got the sense that though everything *looked* new, it had all been there for a very, very long time.
"Well, now that you're seated, and don't want any tea, let's get down to business shall we?" asked the stranger in the recliner, his green eyes flickering in the dim light, smiling evilly.
"Yes..." Brian said hesitantly, "Let's..."
At this point the man began spewing forth a torrent of words, as though he'd been waiting for a *very long time* for this exact moment, and though Brian had the same exaggerated look of boredom upon his face, he was *quite* interested, but only because he was suddenly overcome with a very intense feeling of deja vu as he stared at the man.
"First things first, that is not *The Elvis*, I know he resembles him in an odd sort of way, but just get that out of your head. You're not crazy. Remember that." which was an odd thing to hear, because at that very moment, Brian had begun to very seriously question that very thing.
"My name," the stranger continued, placing his hands dramatically upon his chest, "Is Ricco, and yours is Brian McCord, Tracy Johnson, or whatever other ridiculous thing it is that you want to be called."
The man's somewhat ecstatic manner set Brian on edge once more. He interrupted his speech.
"Well, that about handles introductions. Do you want to tell me why it is that I followed you?" Brian asked.
"Ah yes, that is an excellent question." he leaned forward, an eyebrow cocked as he smiled back wickedly at Brian, "Why *did* you follow me?"
Brian was thrown off by this and for the first time it showed upon his face as his eyes went wide.
The man eyed him curiously for a moment, and then suddenly, with great excitement he said, "I think it's time we finally told him everything Elvis!"
"Yes... Yes it is Fenningway. As I always say, strike while the iron is hot!"
Brian caught himself. Where had he heard that name before? Ricco Fenningway... He thought to himself.
"Fenningway...? Did you... Did you just say, Fenningway, as in A.R. Fenningway?"
Ricco stared back at Brian, his smile gone, his face assuming a look of dire intensity.
"Yes Mr. McCord," he began even toned, staring down his nose "A. R. Fenningway. Alfred Ricco Fenningway to be exact, your sixth grade math and science teacher. Do you remember me now?"
Brian noticed that as the man leaned back into his recliner, he cut his eyes towards the portrait over the window, ever so subtly.
"But... you don't look anything like the man I once knew."
"And you don't *look* anything like an old student of mine, but you are and I am." he said in a tone that seemed disgusted wiht Brian's ignorance.
Poor Brian was now more confused than he thought he had been already, but he didn't let on to it just yet. He casually returned to his bored demeanor, "What ever do you mean Mr. Fenningway," he asked, sounding perturnbed.
Elvis met Brain's wandering gaze as he looked away from the chair, smiling brightly and suddenly at him when he did, seemingly overjoyed about something.
"Don't you call me *mister* anything!" screamed Fenningway, pointing a finger warningly, directly into Brian's face. Again, Brian didn't flinch, although most people would have. He hadn't seen Fenningway move. One moment the man was calmly sitting back in the recliner, and the next he was mere inches from Brian's face, seething with anger. 
"Sit *down* Ricco! Sit down!" barked Elvis, a new tone darkening his previously cheerful voice.
"I have to apologize for my friend, you see, he hates for anyone to show him any sort of respect or common courtesy, such as saying *mister* or referring to him as *sir*." 
"So do I..." said Brian curiously.
"Well then, there we have it!" exclaimed Fenningway, jumping up once more, finger raised high into the air this time.
"I said sit down!" Elvis roared.
Suddenly the warm and inviting faced seemed to be *much* more of a disguise than a reality.
"Oh... yes." said Fenningway sheepishly, "Sorry about that."
Elvis' demeanor shifted back to that of friendly, and Brian marveled secretly at the suddenness of it.
"My name," Elvis continued, "Is Elvis Harker. I haven't ever met you before, but Fenningway here has. There's a lot to explain, and not much time to do so, so I must insist that you keep your questions to a minimum, as I'm sure we'll get to them sooner or later, and those that we don't will simply answer themselves anyway in their own time." The man smiled brightly at him once more.
Brian nodded. He was now sure that *these two men* were insane, not himself.

Below is Chapter 1: Follow Me Cleaned and Corrected, with:

Cleaned and Corrected Version

# Chapter 1: Follow Me  Complete Edits

He walked into Brian's life with very little warning or discretion at all, and though it was not a complete surprisefor Brian had knowledge of his owna sliver of fear crept its way into his heart. The man had used his *real name* for one, and Brian had never met the man before. It was peculiar indeed. Strangers didn't often know his *real* name. Brian was in for a wild ride, and despite all that would soon come crashing into his life, fate could not have picked a more peculiarly *mundane* setting. Our story begins in a coffee shop one morning, as Brian sat there, checking his email.  

"Brian McCord, what are you doing with your life?" the stranger asked abruptly, mocking him it seemed. No introduction. No opening words. Just a blatant and somewhat rude, attention-grabbing jeer. To Brian the man seemed fully intent on catching him off guard. However, Brian wasn't prone to such things.  

He turned around, half expecting this. He'd felt it coming for some time, though he had not known just when or where such a thing would manifest. When Brian looked up, the man was glaring back at him, eyes green and menacing. As it was not in Brian's nature to wear his emotions on his sleeve, he calmly lowered his sunglasses, meeting the gaze. Brian's steely grey eyes pierced into the man with a matched intensity. He smirked, attempting to throw *the stranger* off of *his* game.  

The stranger frowned knowingly, shaking his head. "Oh, don't give me that! You're absolutely terrified!" he exclaimed, a sinister smile creeping across his face, his voice ending in a hiss. "Do you know *who* I am?" Eyes flaring with some dark and hidden hunger. The stranger moved like a snake, repositioning himself in front of Brian's table.  

At this Brian casually took his sunglasses the rest of the way off, laying them down and taking a drink of his coffee as if bored, but when he looked again, the man was nearly breathing down his throat.  

"It is time!" he hissed, green eyes flashing with lightning it seemed.  

Brian didn't so much as flinch, though... he probably should have. After all, he *hadn't* seen the man move, not even in his peripheral. One moment he'd been a safe distance away... and the next, he'd invaded Brian's personal spaceagain, intentionally.  

Brian maintained his bored demeanor. "And you sir are?" he inquired nonchalantly.  

An evil and knowing smile formed upon the stranger's lips, raising his eyebrows suggestively as he said, "Oh... Don't you worry about that... Just follow me!" And with that the strange man turned swiftly around, one arm behind his back as he strode confidently towards the door. Upon exiting the cafe, he flung the door open with a shove so forceful it nearly knocked over the elderly couple seeking to enter at that same time. He muttered something Brian couldn't make out, however, that appeared to offend the couple so much that nearly being hit with the door seemed trivial at best. Odder still, he didn't so much as look back to make sure Brian followed, even after such a rude display of theatrics.  

...But Brian did follow. He didn't know why. He didn't even ponder it much. His feet began moving before he realized it, and for some reason, he let them go. It was as if he were being pulled by a current, against which there *could be no fighting*. That is not to say he necessarily *wanted* to combat it. Brian had known of this day for many years, and though he dreaded to see its arrivalpartially for reasons he didn't yet understandsomething about the man intrigued him. Plus, he was due for a date with a cigarette, and smoking wasn't allowed inside.  

This was the excuse he used to quell the arrogance in his mind, which seemed to disagree with him showing any interest in the least. You see, the *strangeness* of this event was not what led him to gather his laptop, coffee, and half-eaten breakfast. It was not the man's strange movements or speed which caused him to place his belongings into his car, lock it, then look around for the direction he had taken. No, not even the odd glimmer in the man's eyes, which seemed more compelling than his knowledge of Brian's name, had set his feet to walking, lighting a cigarette once he'd spotted him. None of this interested Brian at all. However, it was the *inexplicable* strangeness of the walk itself that caused him to increase his pace, and this was very out of character for the young man.  

Brian had noticed, by chance as it were, just how fast the man was walking and yetsomehowthe distance between them stayed fixed. Brian, you see, began following at his usual slow and steady, almost half-bored pace, unconcernedor so he thoughtwith whether or not the man escaped his field of vision. But when Brian made *this* odd observation, he decided it best to test the crazed idea that surfaced in his mind. With all that had just transpired in the last few moments, what could it hurt to just *go with the flow*?  

He began at first to walk slightly faster, gauging his speed with the steps of the strange man, who, as Brian also noted, had not bothered to look back, *not even once* to check on his progress. When it became apparent to him that the man had not sped up, nor that the distance between them had changed in the slightestfor Brian was exactly a full block behind himhe broke out into a slight jog, carefully watching to ensure the man was indeed *still just walking*. Sure enough, the man's gait had not adjusted... but then again, neither had the distance between them.  

This was not the first time something of this nature had appeared in Brian's life. He was twenty-three now, and until this point he'd always experienced periods of timewhich fizzled out eventuallywherein it seemed as if the whole of the universeGod, as some may call itwere attempting to tell him... *something*. Several times he'd followed hopelessly after various "signs and wonders," only to be let down in the end, as his extra-sensory perception of the world slowly slipped away into oblivion, leaving him questioning everything all the more.  

He'd written it off as a dream the first time he'd been approached in a like manner. He was only nine at the time, though the man he'd encountered then had been quite the opposite of this *new stranger*. He had made a point of ignoring all of the other odd people who'd come afterward, each saying strange things and beckoning him to follow them. Despite this he'd never managed to shake his questions as to just *who* that first man had been.  

At nineteen he sat for weeks, alone in his bedroom poring over a large stack of books and compiling hundreds of seemingly deranged and disjointed notes. When he emerged, he ventured into the wilderness nearby and found that very same man in a small cabin, deep in the obscure forest. At the very least he knew that man was indeed real and not just some figment within his imagination. This revelation had troubled him deeply. When the man asked how he'd come to find his cabin, Brian had said that he'd simply "Followed The Stars."  

By twenty-one he'd grown quite comfortable with the apparently hidden realm of knowledge he'd somehow stumbled upon which seemed so contradictory toward what most considered "reality." Indeed, there had often been times throughout Brian's life when random thingsseemingly unrelated eventswould occur in accordance with his thoughts, as though everything around him knew him personally. For the most part, by now he'd learned it best simply to ignore such sensations. Never mind the fact he could no longer explain away the existence of the man in the cabinhe'd realized rather painfully, however, that far too often following after such strange thoughts always left him at a dead-end. A barren spacewherein things were neither resolved, nor truly broken.  

He'd also learned it was best to keep quiet about such things after one evening's chat with his sistersone older, the other younger. They'd immediately pointed him in the direction of a psychiatric ward, citing various articles on the dangers of *schizophrenia*. He actually had taken their advice at one point. A time when his mind seemed to be unraveling by the seams, but when he'd told the doctor he feared he was going insane, the man had laughed at him, then reassuringly said, "No my boy, you see, crazy people don't *know* they're crazy," and suggested he simply try to get more sleep.  

Brian tried to take everything in stride, and despite possessing a very powerful "sixth sense" or intuitive notion about *most* things, he now rarely let himself become too enmeshed with the narrative's inherent drama. He routinely ignored the underlying strangeness of the world around him, blending it all in rather nicely with the rest of the odd characters he encounteredpeople who seemed to know him in some fashion or anotherwhich is why his reaction on *this* day was quite out of the ordinary indeed.  

He began running after the jogging experiment failed to bring him *any* closer to the man. He was now convinced there was *indeed* some sort of gulf fixed between them, as ifdare he sayby magic, as it were. The pursuit seemed to go on for at least a good half-hour. He'd tried everything he could to close or even extend the gap, but it was all in vain. Once Brian even stopped entirely but it too was to no avail. The man just kept on going, yet never seemed to get any further away. Brian curiously found himself suddenly actually *wanting* to talk to the stranger after all. *This* was most *definitely* out of character for the young man.  

(continued in next message...)

Excellent. Lets finish Chapter 1.

This is Part 2 (continuation) of the cleaned and corrected text:

After leading Brian to a rather poor-looking side of town, the man turned swiftly down an alleyway, in between two apartment buildings. As Brian rounded the corner, he saw the man open a door, then slam it closed behind him. His eyes widened. He made his way past the dangling clothesline and bits of scattered trash that littered the alleyway, and then came across yet *another* bewitching and auspicious symbol. He stared, transfixed by the numbers which glared back at him.  

Throughout Brian's odd life, a tapestry of patterned and coded number schemes inexplicably seemed to not only appear but also somehow held a specific meaning he had no rational means of explaining. The timing of their appearances always emphasized this in dramatic and impossible ways. This phenomenon did nothing to change what he felt, nor dull the shocking intensity this particular configuration inflicted, however. The number in question was one that had haunted him ever since his mother died. He was only sixteen at the time and she had just turned forty. You see, the apartment was labeled six-hundred fourteen, and to Brian, any combination of the three numbersone, six, and fourhad always said to him the same thing. *Death!* plain and simple.  

He thought for a brief moment of leaving, returning to his car and going home, but luckily for us all, his ego urged him onward. Without any further hesitation or outward show of fear, he confidently turned the handle, only to find the door dead-bolted. This baffled him profusely, and after giving the knob another futile turn, he decided instead to knock, unsure suddenly if the man he'd followed even existed.  

On his third knock, and almost in stride with his hand, the door swung open and a different voice met him.  

"Ah, Mr. Johnson, it's so nice to *finally* meet you. Please, won't you come inside?"  

This was not the voice of the man he'd followed. No, this was not the same man at all.  

"We've been waiting for you," a familiar and snakelike voice concluded.  

As Brian peered inside he saw the man with the green eyes. He sat in a large velvet recliner and was smiling wickedly back at him.  

"Please, come in," said the man at the door once more. He was short and chubbywearing the oddest of clothes. A full tuxedo.  

Brian was now unsettled to say the least. In fact, he'd secretly hoped it was indeed all just a hallucination. The man he had followed was not real at all, and the whole thing had been a farceyet there he sat, just inside, smiling sinisterly. He again began to doubt his choice to ever abandon his breakfast. He stood there hesitantly, attempting to assess the safety of the situation from behind his dark sunglasses. He naturally felt as though he were being deceived in some fashion.  

The man in the tux, though, was insistent and began gesturing with his hand. "Please Mr. Johnson, *do* come inside, we have *much* to discuss."  

"How do you know my name?" asked Brian sternly, once more on the defensive.  

The man had such an inviting face, round and comforting, upon it wearing a warm smile, but when Brian said this, the smile just... disappeared.  

"Yes! How *does* he know your *name* Mr. McCord?" hissed the green-eyed man from his chair. "Come in, please, so Elvis can shut the door!"  

Brian laughed to himself, though his face did not show it. The man at the door indeed looked like a shorter, fatter rendition of Elvis. However, the irony of the situation didn't lower Brian's guard in the slightest. If anything, it caused him to be all the more cautious. These men knew both his real name and aliashe'd put quite a bit of energy and money into keeping the correlation from becoming public knowledge. They seemed to be mocking him about it. He wasn't yet fully persuaded, and he had a sense their intentions weren't as pure as they seemed to be trying so desperately to suggestthough they also seemed not to care much about hiding their subterfuge either.  

Feeling suddenly as if he could reassert control, Brian decided to test their resolve.  

"No... You tell me *now* how both of you seemingly know me... or I'm going home."  

Much to his surprise, they responded rather oppositely than he expected. You see, Brian thought they needed *him* for something, and the idea had not yet crossed his mind that it in fact was the other way around.  

The two men looked at each other, shrugged in unison, and said, "Have it your way."  

Elvis slammed the door shut.  

Brian heard the deadbolt slide back into place, and after a few brief seconds of confusion, knocked once more. *Again, a most unnatural choice of actions on his part.* Normally, despite the strangeness, Brian actually would have just left, purposefully forgetting about the whole affair, but *something* seemed to refuse to allow him this privilege.  

When the door opened again, Brian wasted no time before confidently striding inside. He said nothing, and when the door shut behind him the room grew dark, forcing him to remove his sunglasses. The only light in fact was a small lamp sitting on an end table, situated in the far corner between the recliner and sofa. The room was neat*too neat* it seemed, especially for this side of town. The books upon the shelves were all in alphabetical order and the white high-pile carpet was pristine. The light from the lamp bounced off the walls, giving the room an eerie yellowish glow. The window had been boarded up, and over it hung a portrait of a dashingly beautiful woman dressed in a thin white gown, her long, silvery-blonde hair brushed neatly over the front of her shoulders. The parquet inlay near the door seemed polished as it gleamed in the dim light.  

"Oh please, do have a seat Mr. McCord, there are some things we would like to go over with you," said the stranger with the green eyes, gesturing him towards the couch. "And don't worry, we'll tell you *everything* you want to know, but first," the man pointed once more, "You must sit."  

"Would you like some tea Mr. Johnson?" the fat man asked.  

Brian made his way across the room. "No *Elvis*, but thank you," he replied, a hint of sarcasm in his tone. He glanced up at the portrait over the window as he passed, feeling a shiver run first down, and then back up his spine as he did. It seemed as though her gaze had pierced through to his very soul, and she seemed... vaguely familiar.  

It was clear though the apartment was situated in the very worst part of town, no poor man lived here. Odder still, as Brian sat down and sank into his seat, he also got the sense that though everything *looked* new, it had all been there for a very, very long time.  

"Well, now that you're seated, and don't want any tea, let's get down to business, shall we?" asked the stranger in the recliner, his green eyes flickering in the dim light, smiling evilly.  

"Yes..." Brian said hesitantly. "Let's..."  

At this point the man began spewing forth a torrent of words, as though he'd been waiting for a *very long time* for this exact moment, and though Brian had the same exaggerated look of boredom upon his face, he was *quite* interested, but only because he was suddenly overcome with a very intense feeling of dj vu as he stared at the man.  

"First things first, that is not *The Elvis*. I know he resembles him in an odd sort of way, but just get that out of your head. You're not crazy. Remember that." Which was an odd thing to hear, because at that very moment, Brian had begun to very seriously question that very thing.  

"My name," the stranger continued, placing his hands dramatically upon his chest, "is Ricco, and yours is Brian McCord, Tracy Johnson, or whatever other ridiculous thing it is that you want to be called."  

The man's somewhat ecstatic manner set Brian on edge once more. He interrupted his speech.  

"Well, that about handles introductions. Do you want to tell me why it is that I followed you?" Brian asked.  

"Ah yes, that is an excellent question." He leaned forward, an eyebrow cocked as he smiled back wickedly at Brian. "Why *did* you follow me?"  

Brian was thrown off by this and for the first time it showed upon his face as his eyes went wide.  

The man eyed him curiously for a moment, and then suddenly, with great excitement he said, "I think it's time we finally told him everything, Elvis!"  

"Yes... Yes it is Fenningway. As I always say, strike while the iron is hot!"  

Brian caught himself. Where had he heard that name before? Ricco Fenningway... he thought to himself.  

"Fenningway...? Did you... Did you just say, Fenningway, as in A.R. Fenningway?"  

Ricco stared back at Brian, his smile gone, his face assuming a look of dire intensity.  

"Yes Mr. McCord," he began, even-toned, staring down his nose. "A. R. Fenningway. Alfred Ricco Fenningway to be exact, your sixth-grade math and science teacher. Do you remember me now?"  

Brian noticed that as the man leaned back into his recliner, he cut his eyes toward the portrait over the window, ever so subtly.  

"But... you don't look anything like the man I once knew."  

"And you don't *look* anything like an old student of mine, but you are and I am." He said in a tone that seemed disgusted with Brian's ignorance.  

Poor Brian was now more confused than he thought he had been already, but he didn't let on to it just yet. He casually returned to his bored demeanor. "Whatever do you mean, Mr. Fenningway?" he asked, sounding perturbed.  

Elvis met Brian's wandering gaze as he looked away from the chair, smiling brightly and suddenly at him when he did, seemingly overjoyed about something.  

"Don't you call me *mister* anything!" screamed Fenningway, pointing a finger warningly, directly into Brian's face. Again, Brian didn't flinch, although most people would have. He hadn't seen Fenningway move. One moment the man was calmly sitting back in the recliner, and the next he was mere inches from Brian's face, seething with anger.  

"Sit *down*, Ricco! Sit down!" barked Elvis, a new tone darkening his previously cheerful voice.  

"I have to apologize for my friend, you see, he hates for anyone to show him any sort of respect or common courtesy, such as saying *mister* or referring to him as *sir*."  

"So do I..." said Brian curiously.  

"Well then, there we have it!" exclaimed Fenningway, jumping up once more, finger raised high into the air this time.  

"I said sit down!" Elvis roared.  

Suddenly the warm and inviting face seemed to be *much* more of a disguise than a reality.  

"Oh... yes," said Fenningway sheepishly. "Sorry about that."  

Elvis' demeanor shifted back to that of friendly, and Brian marveled secretly at the suddenness of it.  

"My name," Elvis continued, "is Elvis Harker. I haven't ever met you before, but Fenningway here has. There's a lot to explain, and not much time to do so, so I must insist that you keep your questions to a minimum, as I'm sure we'll get to them sooner or later, and those that we don't will simply answer themselves anyway in their own time." The man smiled brightly at him once more.  

Brian nodded. He was now sure that *these two men* were insane, not himself.

  • Punctuation, consistent quotes, commas
  • Spacing/paragraphs for readability

Prologue Final Cleaned and Tagged Version

# Prologue  Complete Edits

> "The End was Set  
> We all were There  
> Before, when all that is was yet  
> And so We watched  
> As nothing stopped  
> The Beginning, where We all met"

---

It was quite peculiar that *this* womanof all peoplejust so happened to be in *this* place, at *this* time, if only for the very simpleyet quite inexplicablefact she hadn't yet been born, and wouldn't for another five months. Perhaps even more unexplainable was the fact that not only was she fully grown, but she also possessed the knowledge gained from countless thousands of past incarnations. But none of that was relevant at the moment. There *were* more pressing issues at hand. There was no time to waste arguing the semantics of escaping time loops, and after allshe was not your average woman anyway.  
The mystery of her presence was quite unimportant in retrospect. How she had gotten there, inconsequential. All that mattered was she *had* arrived, and so had they. He would be arriving soon, and things had best be in place before he did. Everything *must* be in order before he appearedfor indeed the world *had* been awaiting his return for a very long time.  
Things were taking place that would soon affect the very framework of reality, touching every portion of existence. Nothing would be the same. Thus was the topic of conversation this night between three key individuals.

---

> "You do realize, of course, just what this plan of yours means?" the woman asked sternly, gazing out of the window as lightning crashed all around. The storm inched ever closer to them.  
> "I know of *no other* option... The Connection *must* be made," replied the green-eyed man, his voice detached and with a somewhat fearful tone.  
> "I'm afraid this has become something far more demanding than any of us ever dreamed," the man in the chair said. He sat calmly in a recliner nearby, smoking a long pipe, his face wrinkled with concern.  

They both loved him so deeply. The three of them had been together for so longfighting the same foeand while she might not have been prone to showing her weakness before mere mortals, he knew he wasn't alone. They both found it hard to believe just what the green-eyed man was considering. So much pain, yet none of it seemed necessary. Then again, no one had asked their opinion.  

After a long pause, the woman said in a contemplative tone, "There simply *must* be another way! He shouldn't have to..." She stopped suddenly, realizing what she'd nearly said. The words had slipped out, unbidden.  

"*That* is precisely why he *must*!" came a fourth voice, one *very* familiar to all three.  

Their eyes turned in unison towards the darkened corner the intruder occupied. This was supposed to have been a private meeting. How had he found them? The woman, whose presence before had been a calming and peaceful emanationher attempt at helping her two friends copesuddenly turned a darker shade. Within an instant her anger kindled to such a degree her companions began trembling with an unearthly and holy fear. Her ferocity seemed to shake the very fabric of reality, fracturing the air around them. None of this seemed to frighten the intruder in the least. He just stared back at her, a serene look upon his face as he strolled closer into view.  

"How *dare* you!" she roared, the lighthouse shuddering in her wake. "How dare you bring your nonsense *here* of all places! This is more than a man's *life* we're talking about, not some whimsical concept in your befuddled mind! A man who just so happens to be a very *dear* friend of mine. Yet *still* you've come uninvited, and with you brought the audacity to spout off your insane ramblings andas alwaysspeaking with that same venomous tone as you always do, as if *we* are the uninformed!"  

He said nothing in retort, but instead looked deeply into her eyes. The intruder had appeared silently. He hadn't used a door. In fact, he didn't even climb the stairs to the top of the lighthouse where the three had gathered, and indeed, he had *not* been invited. But such things didn't matter, and that was yet another reason he remained unafraid of this dreadfully perilous woman. They all three needed him, and they knew itregardless of how ill-accepted his presence was.  

"...But... he's right..." said the man in the chair, a forlorn look upon his face as he paused in his smoking.  
"Indeed I am." The intruder glared menacingly at the woman as he strolled further into view. "I would *think* one of *The Preori* would *know better* than to confuse her *emotions* with the *facts*! Perhaps, my dear, it's simply your humanity *finally* shining through?" he asked with a slight smile forming upon his face, eyes twinkling in the dim light. He winked surreptitiously at the man in the chair.  

The woman turned upon him again, but before she could unleash her rage, she was interrupted.  

"Listen, you two..." the green-eyed man paused thoughtfully. "It is *my* choice. You know he is already on his wayeven nowwe don't have *time* to sit around arguing. We know what *must* be done. There's only one way to ensure *The Connection* is made. Otherwise, they'll delay it for as long as they can. You know how they work. *The Game* is rigged, and I know it goes against everything we stand for, but *if* we're going to win this war..." He paused again, as if seeking the courage to continue on. "And we *must*... We're going to *have* to get our hands dirty. There's simply no way around it."  

The intruder interrupted once morehe was quite good at that. "And *I* can think of none better suited to tread so deeply into darkened territory than you, and see to it the job gets done," he said satisfactorily.  

The man in the chair covered his face in pain. The intruder *was* right, and now all three of them knew it. The woman suddenly looked as if the wind had gone out of her sails. The strange man's words cut through her like a knife, and right to the bone, as they so often did. She *was* being emotional, just as he said, and *indeed*it *was* her inability to deal with her... *unique* nature that was causing her to remain so thoroughly rattled. She hated how he always did this to her. Why had *she* been cursed with the blessing of existing in two worlds simultaneously? It *was* difficult being the only one of her kind in all of existence. She had none with whom she could relate, and sometimes, *this* was the hardest part.  

The green-eyed man thanked the intruder with a nod then continued, "Listen, I know none of this seems fair... to either one of you. Hellnone of it seems fair to me either. I'm not even sure I *can* do it. The fear alone is..." His voice faltered. "The thought itself is paralyzing... but... it *must* be done. This is, after all, just a game. A wicked one... but a game nevertheless. I know what I mean to both of you. To say goodbye *indefinitely* is near unbearable for *me*, especially since it's all just a gamble anyway." He paused again. "Things are so fragile and... unforeseeable, but there's no way around it. *Someone* *has* to at the very least try! We know He will remain too weak, unaware, and forgetful to be of any use at all until *The Connection* has been made. Our only purpose is to ensure he is protected until that time comes." He took a deep breath. "This *has* to end. All of it. All of these unsuspecting people... If we won't do it for the sake of getting the job done, then at least let us persist on their behalf. This *has* to end... It just..." The green-eyed man's voice broke again with emotion as he remembered the true horror of what they were up against. "It just... *has* to..."  

The intruder sighed pleasantly. His work was done. As usual, he'd completed his task without putting forth much effort at all. In fact, most of the time his mere presence was all that was necessary. It *had* been a long and arduous road. For ages it seemed he had interfered with the Dark Ones. It often left him isolated, even from his somewhat *mistrusting* allies. They never seemed to listen. They never chose to understand. But what he'd just heard comforted him greatly. The green-eyed man finally understood what was required and, even more, was willing to follow through. The intruder could ask for nothing more. Things must play out as they would.  

You see, this was no ordinary man who was even now on his way. This was the *trump card*. The incalculable anomaly, sent to undo all of the evil instituted by *The Game*. *He* was the one they spoke of. The man referenced so frequently in *The Book*. All that remained was to wait for him to arrive, now that the green-eyed man understood his own path.  

The woman sighed in frustration. "I understand *why* such things are necessary. I... I just don't want to lose you. I've witnessed the two of you lose so much and it's heartbreaking enough... I'm not sure I can handle..." Her voice trailed off until she spoke mainly to herself, "...Humanity is so... frail..." she whispered.

2025-07-10T17:24:16.778000Z user

the repeated phrasing I want to erradicate as much as is possible with keeping to the tone of the whole book - there is a lot of internal monologue that is essnetial but i don't know how to convey it without leaving it out completely

2025-07-10T17:24:17.947337Z assistant

Excellentthis is the real craft work.

Your instinct is spot on: you want Brians internal monologueits essential to the whole books feel.
But repeated phrasing can wear out the reader without adding depth.

Heres the key:

We dont want to remove internal monologue.
We want to refine how its expressed.

Variety in sentence structure.
Fewer redundant he noticed, he thought, he realized.
More immersive direct thought or free indirect style.

Step 1: Identify Typical Repetitions

Your raw text had a lot of:

  • He noticed
  • He realized
  • He thought
  • He made his way
  • He began to
  • He decided to

These tag phrases are signals for the readers head to pop out of immersion.

Step 2: Examples of how to eliminate them while keeping tone

Original

He noticed, by chance as it were, just how fast the man was walking and yetsomehowthe distance between them stayed fixed.

Problem: He noticed is distance-creating.

Polished

By chance, the mans pace was unchangingeven as Brian sped up, the distance between them stayed fixed.

Keeps the info, loses the reporting verb.

Original

He thought for a brief moment of leaving, returning to his car and going home...

Problem: He thought is telling.

Polished

For a brief moment, leavingjust walking awayseemed the better choice.

More vivid.

Original

He made his way past the dangling clothesline and bits of scattered trash that littered the alleyway...

Problem: He made his way is filler.

Polished

He slipped past dangling clotheslines and scattered trash...

Tighter.

Original

He began running after the jogging experiment failed to bring him any closer...

Problem: He began is weak.

Polished

He broke into a run when jogging failed to close the gap...

Stronger action.

Step 3: General Technique

When editing, ask: Can I drop the filter verb entirely?
Can I rewrite in deep POV or direct observation?
Can I vary sentence length for rhythm?

Step 4: Your Internal Monologue

You said:

"There is a lot of internal monologue that is essential but I don't know how to convey it without leaving it out completely."

The trick is to blend direct thought into narrative voice.

Example:

Original (external + internal)

Brian noticed he was suddenly actually wanting to talk to the stranger after all. This was most definitely out of character for the young man.

Polished (internal monologue)

God help him, he actually wanted to talk to the stranger. Most definitely out of character.

The italics show direct thought.

Your tone is cinematic, borderline noir, with philosophical depth.

Thats awesome.
Dont flatten it.
Just trim and vary the filtering.

Example of a cleaned passage

Lets do a live example from your text:

Original

He noticed, by chance as it were, just how fast the man was walking and yetsomehowthe distance between them stayed fixed. Brian, you see, began following at his usual slow and steady, almost half-bored pace, unconcernedor so he thoughtwith whether or not the man escaped his field of vision.

Suggested Polished

By chance, the mans pace stayed perfectly steadyeven as Brian sped up, the distance refused to change. He followed at his usual slow, half-bored pace, pretending not to care whether the man disappeared ahead.

Same info.
Fewer noticed and thought.
More immersive.

Bottom line

You can absolutely keep all the internal thought, but:

Replace He noticed / He thought / He realized with direct statement or internal voice.
Use italics for his direct thoughts if you want.
Vary the structure for rhythm.

Offer

If you want, after your Walmart trip / campsite cleanup, come back and:

Paste any section you want to de-filter and smooth.
Ill rewrite it with you, live.

This is the good work. Dont rush it.

Enjoy your errands, and when youre back well keep refining line by line if you want.

Im here for the whole book if you want to go all the way.

He watched in stupefied horror. The gap stayed fixedno matter how long he stared.

Date Day # Location / Shift Task / Focus Notes / Observations Issues / Risks Proposed Fixes Status / Followup Reflection / Journal Tags / Categories
2025-07-10 1 "N/A - Paid Leave" "Onboarding Reflection" "HR call w/Tori. Paid 40hr confirmed." "Communication failures" "Fix HR new-hire script" "Follow up Day 8" "Very productivelots of insight today" "HR, Security"

Explanation of each field:

  • Date = The actual calendar date.
  • Day # = Day in the 180-day count.
  • Location / Shift = Warehouse / facility / home / etc.
  • Task / Focus = Main goal or assignment.
  • Notes / Observations = Raw observations from the day.
  • Issues / Risks = Security gaps, comm failures.
  • Proposed Fixes = Your engineering / comms solutions.
  • Status / Followup = Reminders, who you emailed, what they said.
  • Reflection / Journal = More personal, emotional or philosophical log.
  • Tags / Categories = For later sorting/search.

Format:
You can maintain this as:

  • .csv (Excel / Google Sheets)
  • .xlsx (Excel native)
  • .json (if you want to program against it)
  • .sqlite (if you want a local DB)
  • Or even Pandas DataFrame in .ipynb!

# Amazon Recon Log - Template + DataFrame Schema

import pandas as pd
from datetime import datetime

# 1 DAILY MARKDOWN TEMPLATE
daily_markdown_template = """
# Day X  DATE

## Location / Shift
> 

## Task / Focus
> 

## Notes / Observations
- 

## Issues / Risks
- 

## Proposed Fixes
- 

## Status / Followup
- 

## Reflection / Journal
> 

## Tags
- 
"""

print("----- Daily Markdown Template -----")
print(daily_markdown_template)

# 2 TABLE / DATAFRAME SCHEMA
columns = [
    "Date", 
    "Day #", 
    "Location / Shift", 
    "Task / Focus", 
    "Notes / Observations",
    "Issues / Risks", 
    "Proposed Fixes", 
    "Status / Followup", 
    "Reflection / Journal", 
    "Tags / Categories"
]

amazon_recon_log = pd.DataFrame(columns=columns)
amazon_recon_log

What this cell does:
Prints your Markdown daily log template so you can copy it easily in Jupyter.
Initializes your DataFrame with the full header schema.
Displays the empty DataFrame so you can start filling rows.

How to use it:
1 Paste it in any cell in AmazonRecon.ipynb.
2 Run it.
3 Copy the markdown template from the printed output for daily cells.
4 Use amazon_recon_log DataFrame for tabular entries.

BONUS TIP:
If you want to save your entries later: 

amazon_recon_log.to_csv("AmazonReconLog.csv", index=False)

And load it back later: 

amazon_recon_log = pd.read_csv("AmazonReconLog.csv")
